dict_list.paragraph: Other dualists have taken the second option (Mills 1996, Lowe 2003): they claim that mental properties do, as a matter of fact, over- determine their effects; while the physical cause is there, so too is an additional mental cause. This would be a curious state of affairs, but it seems possible. Even though it gives us an inelegant world, and one The Exclusion Problem 75 where it doesn’t seem mentality is causally needed, perhaps there is room here to save our intuitions about mental causation. In recent years, a number of philosophers who reject the ­traditional physicalist picture of mental phenomena have sought to avoid the ex- clusion argument by turning away from traditional property dualism to something like Russellian monism (see Chapter 4.) On that view, mental properties—or proto-mental properties that are not ­themselves mental but contain the seeds of mentality—actually ground all of the physical properties in the world. In contrast to the traditional ­picture, on which mental properties do not emerge until you get to the level of brains, Russellian monists see the world as having a mental or ­proto-mental base which ultimately explains the physical phenomena. Though this requires the denial of completeness, the Russellian mon- ist will argue that they can do so in an empirically ­unobjectionable way. For a critical discussion of the Russellian strategy as a solution to the exclusion problem see Howell (2015), and for a response see Alter and Coleman (2021). Mind in a Physical World, Cambridge, MA: MIT Press. OVERVIEWS Bennett, K. 2007. “Mental Causation.” Philosophy Compass 2: 316–37. Moore, Dwayne. 2018. “Mind and the Causal Exclusion Problem.” Internet Ency- clopedia of Philosophy. https://iep.

dict_list.question: What is the relationship between the Russellian monist view and the idea of completeness?
dict_list.answer: The Russellian monist view requires the denial of completeness, meaning that the world is not fully explained by physical properties. However, the Russellian monist will argue that this denial is empirically unobjectionable, and can be supported by empirical evidence.

dict_list.question: What is the Exclusion Problem and why is it significant in the context of dualism?
dict_list.answer: The Exclusion Problem is significant because it challenges the idea that mental properties can have a causal role in the world. If mental properties cannot cause physical effects without being excluded by the physical cause, then it appears that they play no causal role at all. This is a problem for dualism, which posits that mental properties are real and have a causal role.

dict_list.paragraph: Other dualists have taken the second option (Mills 1996, Lowe 2003): they claim that mental properties do, as a matter of fact, over- determine their effects; while the physical cause is there, so too is an additional mental cause. This would be a curious state of affairs, but it seems possible. In contrast to the traditional ­picture, on which mental properties do not emerge until you get to the level of brains, Russellian monists see the world as having a mental or ­proto-mental base which ultimately explains the physical phenomena. Though this requires the denial of completeness, the Russellian mon- ist will argue that they can do so in an empirically ­unobjectionable way. dict_list.metadata: Philosophy of Mind_ 50 Puzzles, Paradoxes, and Thought Experiments by Torin Alter & Robert J
dict_list.question: What is the "Exclusion Problem" in the context of dualism?
dict_list.answer: The Exclusion Problem is the challenge of explaining how mental properties can cause physical effects without being excluded by the physical cause. In other words, it is the problem of how to reconcile the idea that mental properties have a causal role with the fact that physical properties are thought to be the only causes of physical effects.

dict_list.paragraph: Other dualists have taken the second option (Mills 1996, Lowe 2003): they claim that mental properties do, as a matter of fact, over- determine their effects; while the physical cause is there, so too is an additional mental cause. This would be a curious state of affairs, but it seems possible. Even though it gives us an inelegant world, and one The Exclusion Problem 75 where it doesn’t seem mentality is causally needed, perhaps there is room here to save our intuitions about mental causation. In recent years, a number of philosophers who reject the ­traditional physicalist picture of mental phenomena have sought to avoid the ex- clusion argument by turning away from traditional property dualism to something like Russellian monism (see Chapter 4.) On that view, mental properties—or proto-mental properties that are not ­themselves mental but contain the seeds of mentality—actually ground all of the physical properties in the world. In contrast to the traditional ­picture, on which mental properties do not emerge until you get to the level of brains, Russellian monists see the world as having a mental or ­proto-mental base which ultimately explains the physical phenomena. Though this requires the denial of completeness, the Russellian mon- ist will argue that they can do so in an empirically ­unobjectionable way. For a critical discussion of the Russellian strategy as a solution to the exclusion problem see Howell (2015), and for a response see Alter and Coleman (2021). RECOMMENDED READING CANONICAL PRESENTATIONS Kim, Jaegwon. 1989. “Mechanism, Purpose, and Explanatory Exclusion.” Philo- sophical Perspectives 3: 77–108. Kim, Jaegwon. 1998. Mind in a Physical World, Cambridge, MA: MIT Press. OVERVIEWS Bennett, K. 2007. “Mental Causation.” Philosophy Compass 2: 316–37. Moore, Dwayne. 2018. “Mind and the Causal Exclusion Problem.” Internet Ency- clopedia of Philosophy. https://iep.
dict_list.metadata: Philosophy of Mind_ 50 Puzzles, Paradoxes, and Thought Experiments by Torin Alter & Robert J
dict_list.question: What is the argument that some philosophers have made in response to the Exclusion Problem?
dict_list.answer: Some philosophers have argued that mental properties can over-determine their effects, meaning that both the physical cause and the mental cause are present and contribute to the effect. This would be a curious state of affairs, but it could potentially provide a way to save our intuitions about mental causation.

question_answer_pairs_string:
**QUESTION:**
What is Russellian monism, and how does it address the Exclusion Problem?

**ANSWER:**
Russellian monism is a view that sees the world as having a mental or proto-mental base that ultimately explains the physical phenomena. On this view, mental properties are not just emergent at the level of brains, but actually ground all of the physical properties in the world. This approach can be seen as a way to avoid the Exclusion Problem by positing that mental properties are fundamental to the world.


**QUESTION:**
What is the relationship between the Russellian monist view and the idea of completeness?

**ANSWER:**
The Russellian monist view requires the denial of completeness, meaning that the world is not fully explained by physical properties. However, the Russellian monist will argue that this denial is empirically unobjectionable, and can be supported by empirical evidence.


**QUESTION:**
What is the Exclusion Problem and why is it significant in the context of dualism?

**ANSWER:**
The Exclusion Problem is significant because it challenges the idea that mental properties can have a causal role in the world. If mental properties cannot cause physical effects without being excluded by the physical cause, then it appears that they play no causal role at all. This is a problem for dualism, which posits that mental properties are real and have a causal role.


**QUESTION:**
What is the "Exclusion Problem" in the context of dualism?

**ANSWER:**
The Exclusion Problem is the challenge of explaining how mental properties can cause physical effects without being excluded by the physical cause. In other words, it is the problem of how to reconcile the idea that mental properties have a causal role with the fact that physical properties are thought to be the only causes of physical effects.


**QUESTION:**
What is the argument that some philosophers have made in response to the Exclusion Problem?

**ANSWER:**
Some philosophers have argued that mental properties can over-determine their effects, meaning that both the physical cause and the mental cause are present and contribute to the effect. This would be a curious state of affairs, but it could potentially provide a way to save our intuitions about mental causation.
